<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 119, 378, 144]]<|/det|>
# Cambridge IGCSE™  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 170, 195, 201]]<|/det|>
CANDIDATE NAME  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 221, 176, 250]]<|/det|>
CENTRE NUMBER  

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[210, 210, 425, 255]]<|/det|>  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[620, 220, 720, 250]]<|/det|>
CANDIDATE NUMBER  

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[737, 210, 905, 255]]<|/det|>  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 276, 348, 293]]<|/det|>
## ADDITIONAL MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 301, 154, 316]]<|/det|>
Paper 1  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[782, 277, 904, 293]]<|/det|>
0606/11  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[782, 301, 904, 316]]<|/det|>
May/June 2021  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[840, 325, 904, 340]]<|/det|>
2 hours  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 355, 393, 370]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 359, 400]]<|/det|>
No additional materials are needed.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 228, 434]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 280, 450]]<|/det|>
Answer all questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 450, 760, 466]]<|/det|>
Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 466, 806, 482]]<|/det|>
Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 482, 562, 497]]<|/det|>
Write your answer to each question in the space provided.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 498, 480, 512]]<|/det|>
Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 513, 359, 527]]<|/det|>
Do not write on any bar codes.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 528, 480, 543]]<|/det|>
You should use a calculator where appropriate.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 543, 880, 573]]<|/det|>
You must show all necessary working clearly; no marks will be given for unsupported answers from a calculator.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 574, 860, 604]]<|/det|>
Give non-exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 634, 218, 649]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 651, 730, 682]]<|/det|>
The total mark for this paper is 80. The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[415, 79, 615, 97]]<|/det|>
Mathematical Formulae  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[453, 139, 576, 159]]<|/det|>
## 1. ALGEBRA  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 171, 255, 191]]<|/det|>
Quadratic Equation  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[131, 201, 400, 221]]<|/det|>
For the equation \(ax^{2} + bx + c = 0\)  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[432, 220, 596, 255]]<|/det|>
\[x = \frac{-b\pm\sqrt{b^{2} - 4ac}}{2a}\]  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 278, 243, 297]]<|/det|>
Binomial Theorem  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[260, 297, 767, 339]]<|/det|>
\[(a + b)^{n} = a^{n} + \binom{n}{1} a^{n - 1}b + \binom{n}{2} a^{n - 2}b^{2} + \ldots +\binom{n}{r} a^{n - r}b^{r} + \ldots +b^{n}\]  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[131, 351, 514, 392]]<|/det|>
where \(n\) is a positive integer and \(\binom{n}{r} = \frac{n!}{(n - r)!r!}\)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 416, 401, 436]]<|/det|>
Arithmetic series \(u_{n} = a + (n - 1)d\)  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[260, 440, 551, 472]]<|/det|>
\[S_{n} = \frac{1}{2} n(a + l) = \frac{1}{2} n\left\{2a + (n - 1)d\right\}\]  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 494, 351, 514]]<|/det|>
Geometric series \(u_{n} = a r^{n - 1}\)  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[260, 515, 445, 580]]<|/det|>
\[S_{n} = \frac{a(1 - r^{n})}{1 - r} (r\neq 1)\] \[S_{\infty} = \frac{a}{1 - r} (|r|< 1)\]  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[415, 617, 611, 637]]<|/det|>
## 2. TRIGONOMETRY  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 650, 171, 668]]<|/det|>
Identities  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[430, 678, 598, 730]]<|/det|>
\[\sin^{2}A + \cos^{2}A = 1\] \[\sec^{2}A = 1 + \tan^{2}A\] \[\csc^{2}A = 1 + \cot^{2}A\]  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 772, 256, 791]]<|/det|>
Formulae for \(\Delta ABC\)  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[418, 798, 608, 838]]<|/det|>
\[\frac{a}{\sin A} = \frac{b}{\sin B} = \frac{c}{\sin C}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[418, 833, 610, 855]]<|/det|>
\[a^{2} = b^{2} + c^{2} - 2bc\cos A\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[457, 860, 571, 890]]<|/det|>
\[\Delta = \frac{1}{2} bc\sin A\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 99, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 146, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 72, 920, 108]]<|/det|>
On the axes, sketch the graph of \(y = 5(x + 1)(3x - 2)(x - 2)\), stating the intercepts with the coordinate axes.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 87, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 120, 866, 393]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 413, 146, 432]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 413, 667, 433]]<|/det|>
Hence find the values of \(x\) for which \(5(x + 1)(3x - 2)(x - 2) > 0\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 413, 920, 432]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 585, 97, 604]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 579, 920, 631]]<|/det|>
Find \(\int_{3}^{5}\left(\frac{1}{x - 1} -\frac{1}{(x - 1)^{2}}\right)\mathrm{d}x,\) giving your answer in the form \(a + \ln b\), where \(a\) and \(b\) are rational numbers.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 611, 920, 630]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 75, 92, 94]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 75, 920, 109]]<|/det|>
The polynomial \(\mathrm{p}(x) = a x^{3} - 9 x^{2} + b x - 6\), where \(a\) and \(b\) are constants, has a factor of \(x - 2\). The polynomial has a remainder of 66 when divided by \(x - 3\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 121, 144, 139]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 121, 379, 139]]<|/det|>
Find the value of \(a\) and of \(b\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 121, 920, 140]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 432, 146, 450]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 432, 920, 465]]<|/det|>
Using your values of \(a\) and \(b\), show that \(\mathrm{p}(x) = (x - 2)\mathrm{q}(x)\), where \(\mathrm{q}(x)\) is a quadratic factor to be found.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 448, 920, 467]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 695, 144, 714]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 695, 672, 714]]<|/det|>
Hence show that the equation \(\mathrm{p}(x) = 0\) has only one real solution.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 694, 920, 714]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 81, 97, 101]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 920, 128]]<|/det|>
The first 3 terms in the expansion of \(\left(a + x\right)^{3}\left(1 - \frac{x}{3}\right)^{5}\), in ascending powers of \(x\), can be written in the form \(27 + bx + cx^{2}\), where \(a\), \(b\) and \(c\) are integers. Find the values of \(a\), \(b\) and \(c\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 109, 920, 128]]<|/det|>
<mark>[8]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 71, 97, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 71, 468, 89]]<|/det|>
The functions f and g are defined as follows.

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[393, 101, 606, 121]]<|/det|>
\[\mathrm{f}(x) = x^{2} + 4x\quad \mathrm{for}\quad x\in \mathbb{R}\]

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[393, 131, 606, 152]]<|/det|>
\[\mathrm{g}(x) = 1 + \mathrm{e}^{2x}\quad \mathrm{for}\quad x\in \mathbb{R}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 180, 146, 198]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 180, 311, 198]]<|/det|>
Find the range of f.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 181, 920, 198]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 350, 146, 368]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 350, 368, 368]]<|/det|>
Write down the range of g.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 351, 920, 368]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 552, 144, 570]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 552, 923, 571]]<|/det|>
Find the exact solution of the equation \(\mathrm{fg}(x) = 21\), giving your answer as a single logarithm. [4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 72, 96, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 144, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 72, 180, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 70, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
Find how many different 5-digit numbers can be formed using the digits 1, 3, 5, 6, 8 and 9. No digit may be used more than once in any 5-digit number.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 85, 920, 104]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 163, 180, 182]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 163, 549, 183]]<|/det|>
How many of these 5-digit numbers are odd?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 163, 920, 182]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 272, 180, 291]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 272, 734, 291]]<|/det|>
How many of these 5-digit numbers are odd and greater than 60 000?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 272, 920, 291]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 473, 144, 492]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 473, 626, 492]]<|/det|>
Given that \(45 \times {}^n\mathrm{C}_4 = (n + 1) \times {}^n + 1\mathrm{C}_5\), find the value of \(n\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 473, 920, 492]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 71, 96, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 71, 146, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 69, 675, 91]]<|/det|>
In this question, all lengths are in metres and time, \(t\), is in seconds.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 102, 851, 400]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 418, 761, 439]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows the displacement–time graph for a runner, for \(0 \leqslant t \leqslant 40\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 450, 180, 469]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 450, 625, 469]]<|/det|>
Find the distance the runner has travelled when \(t = 40\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 450, 918, 469]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 542, 180, 560]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 541, 923, 561]]<|/det|>
On the axes, draw the corresponding velocity–time graph for the runner, for \(0 \leqslant t \leqslant 40\).

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 574, 855, 880]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 146, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 902, 92]]<|/det|>
A particle, \(P\), moves in a straight line such that its displacement from a fixed point at time \(t\) is \(s\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 97, 594, 123]]<|/det|>
The acceleration of \(P\) is given by \(\left(2t + 4\right)^{-\frac{1}{2}}\), for \(t > 0\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 133, 180, 152]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 133, 784, 152]]<|/det|>
Given that \(P\) has a velocity of 9 when \(t = 6\), find the velocity of \(P\) at time \(t\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 133, 920, 152]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 475, 180, 494]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 470, 710, 496]]<|/det|>
Given that \(s = \frac{1}{3}\) when \(t = 6\), find the displacement of \(P\) at time \(t\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 475, 920, 494]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 97, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>8</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 70, 586, 92]]<|/det|>
DO NOT USE A CALCULATOR IN THIS QUESTION.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 98, 915, 128]]<|/det|>
A curve has equation \(y = \big(2 - \sqrt{3}\big)x^{2} + x - 1\). The \(x\)-coordinate of a point \(A\) on the curve is \(\frac{\sqrt{3} + 1}{2 - \sqrt{3}}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 134, 144, 152]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 131, 920, 168]]<|/det|>
Show that the coordinates of \(A\) can be written in the form \(\left(p + q\sqrt{3}, r + s\sqrt{3}\right)\), where \(p, q, r\) and \(s\) are integers.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 152, 920, 170]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 75, 146, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 73, 920, 109]]<|/det|>
Find the \(x\)-coordinate of the stationary point on the curve, giving your answer in the form \(a + b\sqrt{3}\) , where \(a\) and \(b\) are rational numbers.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 87, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 73, 96, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>9</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 144, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 73, 185, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 72, 920, 108]]<|/det|>
Write \(6xy + 3y + 4x + 2\) in the form \((ax + b)(cy + d)\), where \(a\), \(b\), \(c\) and \(d\) are positive integers. [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 243, 181, 262]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 242, 863, 262]]<|/det|>
Hence solve the equation \(6\sin \theta \cos \theta +3\cos \theta +4\sin \theta +2 = 0\) for \(0^{\circ}< \theta < 360^{\circ}\). [4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 81, 146, 100]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 75, 920, 102]]<|/det|>
Solve the equation \(\frac{1}{2}\sec \left(2\phi +\frac{\pi}{4}\right) = \frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}\) for \(-\pi < \phi < \pi\), where \(\phi\) is in radians. Give your

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 109, 331, 128]]<|/det|>
answers in terms of \(\pi\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 109, 920, 128]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 104, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>10</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 472, 89]]<|/det|>
In this question all lengths are in centimetres.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[316, 100, 670, 521]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 556, 920, 592]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows a shaded shape. The arc \(AB\) is the major arc of a circle, centre \(O\), radius 10. The line \(AB\) is of length 15, the line \(OC\) is of length 25 and the lengths of \(AC\) and \(BC\) are equal.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 604, 144, 623]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 604, 690, 623]]<|/det|>
Show that the angle \(AOB\) is 1.70 radians correct to 2 decimal places.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 604, 920, 623]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 759, 146, 778]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 759, 462, 778]]<|/det|>
Find the perimeter of the shaded shape.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 759, 920, 778]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 303, 144, 322]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 303, 423, 322]]<|/det|>
Find the area of the shaded shape.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 304, 920, 322]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]
